docs.abstract: Linda Goetz Holmes letter says Japan's former prisoners of war, including some 5,300 surviving Americans, deserve compensation from Japanese corporations, not as 'reparations' but as wage compensation issue (S)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''The Trial of Slobodan Milosevic'' (editorial, Feb. 11):    It is disappointing that you take the customary and overly simplistic view in the matter of the Milosevic trial.     As long as the charges against Slobodan Milosevi...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Trial of Slobodan Milosevic'' (editorial, Feb. 11): It is disappointing that you take the customary and overly simplistic view in the matter of the Milosevic trial. As long as the charges against Slobodan Milosevic run on left-over public relations fumes; as long as the crimes committed against Serbs in these wars are belittled and swept under the rug while those perpetrated against all others are overblown or misrepresented; and as long as the role of the West in fueling the Balkan wars is not scrutinized, there will be no justice served, and rendering final justice will be left to the court of history.
docs.abstract: Andre Huzsvai letter disputes Fewbruary 11 editorial on war crimes trial of former Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic in The Hague

headline.main: A Search for Justice in The Hague

docs.snippet: Prosecutors in Hamburg said they were preparing to charge a former SS officer, Friedrich Engel, 93, in connection with the killing of at least 246 Italians in 1944 and 1945. An Italian court convicted him of the killings in absentia in 1999 and se...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Hamburg said they were preparing to charge a former SS officer, Friedrich Engel, 93, in connection with the killing of at least 246 Italians in 1944 and 1945. An Italian court convicted him of the killings in absentia in 1999 and sentenced him to life in prison. The case against Mr. Engel, who denies having killed anyone or having ordered any killings, came to national attention last year when German television reported that he was living in Hamburg. Victor Homola (NYT)
docs.abstract: Prosecutors in Hamburg say they are preparing to charge former SS officer, Friedrich Engel, 93, in connection with killing of at least 246 Italians in 1944 and 1955; Engel denies killing anyone; case came to national attention last year when German television reported he was living in Hamburg (S)

docs.snippet: Foday Sankoh, the leader of the rebel group responsible for killing and mutilating thousands of civilians, will not be freed even after a state of emergency is lifted across the country, Justice Minister Solomon Berewa announced. He will be kept i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Foday Sankoh, the leader of the rebel group responsible for killing and mutilating thousands of civilians, will not be freed even after a state of emergency is lifted across the country, Justice Minister Solomon Berewa announced. He will be kept in detention despite the rebel group's insistence that he be released. The government and the rebels have declared the civil war over. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)
docs.abstract: Sierra Leone government says Foday Sankoh, leader of rebel group responsible for killing and mutilating thousands of civilians, will not be freed even after state of emergency is lifted across country (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Sierra Leone: No Freedom For Rebel Leader

docs.snippet: Prosecutors at Slobodan Milosevic's war crimes trial moved swiftly today to try to show that the ousted Yugoslav leader knew or should have known of the actions of his underlings, did nothing and therefore bears responsibility for any atrocities t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors at Slobodan Milosevic's war crimes trial moved swiftly today to try to show that the ousted Yugoslav leader knew or should have known of the actions of his underlings, did nothing and therefore bears responsibility for any atrocities they committed. The first witness called by the prosecution, Mahmat Bakalli, a Kosovo Albanian who once was that province's Communist leader, said he had warned Mr. Milosevic early on about police abuses in Kosovo.
docs.abstract: Prosecutors at Slobodan Milosevic's war crimes trial in the Hague move swiftly to show that ousted Yugoslav leader knew or should have known of actions of his underlings, did nothing and therefore bears responsibility for any atrocities they committed; testimony of first witness former Kosovo Communist leader Mahmat Bakalli described; Bakalli says he warned Milosevic early in conflict about police abuses (M)

headline.main: A Witness Says Milosevic Knew Early About Abuses in Kosovo

docs.snippet: NATO dismissed as ''pure speculation'' reports today that an attempt to arrest the former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, failed because a French officer had tipped off the local police about the operation.    At least two European newspape...
docs.lead_paragraph: NATO dismissed as ''pure speculation'' reports today that an attempt to arrest the former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, failed because a French officer had tipped off the local police about the operation. At least two European newspapers carried allegations that information had been leaked about an air and ground raid last week by peacekeeping forces in southeastern Bosnia to detain Mr. Karadzic, one of the men most wanted by the United Nations war crimes tribunal.
docs.abstract: NATO dismisses reports that attempt to arrest former Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, failed because French officer tipped off local police about operation (S)

headline.main: NATO Rejects Claim That Tip Foiled Arrest

docs.snippet: Slobodan Milosevic made clear today, as he did during his three-day opening statement, that he will fight every moment of what may be a two-year trial. He may not acknowledge the  authority of the tribunal at The Hague to try him for war crimes, b...
docs.lead_paragraph: Slobodan Milosevic made clear today, as he did during his three-day opening statement, that he will fight every moment of what may be a two-year trial. He may not acknowledge the authority of the tribunal at The Hague to try him for war crimes, but he showed that he could quickly adapt to its interrogatory style. He cross-examined his first witness, Mahmut Bakalli, an Albanian politician. The two men sparred over differing visions of Kosovo, the southern province of Serbia, which is considered sacred ground for Serbs and Albanians alike, though Albanians are by far in the majority.
docs.abstract: Former Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic displays flair for courtroom tactics while acting as own lawyer in war crimes trial in the Hague; conducts combative cross-examination of Mahmut Bakalli, first prosecution witness who was high Communist Party official; pounds Bakalli with questions intended to show Albanians in Kosovo turned to 'terrorism' in quest for separate state leading to war in 1999 in which over 5,000 Kosovo Albanians died; is charged with genocide and other crimes during three wars in Balkans in 1990's--in Bosnia, Croatia and Kosovo; photo (M)

headline.main: Combative Milosevic Displays A Flair for Courtroom Tactics

docs.snippet: After more than two years of civil war in Chechnya, Russian lawmakers have opened a new dialogue with Chechen political figures in hopes of setting terms for direct talks between President Vladimir V. Putin and the rebel leaders he has branded ter...
docs.lead_paragraph: After more than two years of civil war in Chechnya, Russian lawmakers have opened a new dialogue with Chechen political figures in hopes of setting terms for direct talks between President Vladimir V. Putin and the rebel leaders he has branded terrorists. The opening of the informal talks in Moscow this month followed the failure of an initiative by Mr. Putin last fall to begin direct talks with Chechen leaders hiding in the northern Caucasus, where guerrilla operations against federal troops continue.
docs.abstract: Russian lawmakers open new dialogue with Chechen political figures after more than two years of civil war in breakaway province in hopes of setting terms for direct talks between President Vladimir V Putin and rebel leaders he has branded as terrorists; failure of fall 2001 peace initiative by Putin noted (M)

headline.main: Chechens and Russians Start Informal Discussions, Hoping Leaders Will Meet for Talks

docs.snippet: A fire in a cafeteria at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague forced a halt in the trial of Slobodan Milosevic. Not long after he arrived in the morning, the former Yugoslav leader was whisked back to prison in the bulletproof car in which he make...
docs.lead_paragraph: A fire in a cafeteria at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague forced a halt in the trial of Slobodan Milosevic. Not long after he arrived in the morning, the former Yugoslav leader was whisked back to prison in the bulletproof car in which he makes his daily trip from the United Nations detention center. Mr. Milosevic's trial is to resume today. Marlise Simons (NYT)
docs.abstract: Fire in cafeteria at war crimes tribunal in The Hague forces halt in trial of Slobodan Milosevic (S)

headline.main: World Briefing: Europe; YUGOSLAVIA: FIRE INTERRUPTS MILOSEVIC TRIAL

docs.snippet: An article on Feb. 19 about a dispute between the United Nations and the Cambodian government over a proposed tribunal to try former Khmer Rouge leaders misspelled the surname of the American ambassador in Phnom Penh, who supported the Cambodian a...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Feb. 19 about a dispute between the United Nations and the Cambodian government over a proposed tribunal to try former Khmer Rouge leaders misspelled the surname of the American ambassador in Phnom Penh, who supported the Cambodian argument. He is Kent Wiedemann, not Weideman.
docs.abstract: Correction of February 19 article about dispute between UN and Cambodian government over proposed tribunal to try former Khmer Rouge leaders for war crimes
